How encouraging that the noticeboard has several members who are not 
blind=
ly prejudiced against Namban tsuba as a group, even if many of 
these are l=
acking in both design and execution.  I remember my 
distress some years ag=
o when, upon being informed of my research on 
the group, a senior member o=
f the To-ken scene in GB replied Oh Dear, 
but he supposed that somebody ha=
d to do it!

The tsuba that Ron describes as being 'made in two pieces' is =

probably one of many tsuba which were made in the mid-C19 for sale to 
for=
eigners in Nagasaki.  These were made in two non-contiguous halves 
that, w=
hen joined together gave the impression of undercutting.  In 
the better of=
 these they were joined by a mimi; in the others they 
were simply soldered=
 together.

The Hozon Namban tsuba posted by Richard is very nice.  The gol=
d 
sleeves that he comments upon appear to be inserts intended to tidy 
up =
the irregularities in the design left by the later addition (or 
should I s=
ay subtraction) of the ryo-hitsu.

Please keep them coming.

Regards, John =
L.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Ron Hartmann" <swords@...> 
wrote=
:
>
> Dear John - 
> 
> Well you tweeked the ego button...will post a photo=
 or two of that 
nice namban early-on this week. May dig out another unique=
ly 
structured namban that I featured in an old JSS/US article years 
back.=
 That one appeared to be made in two pieces and the "sides" 
somehow "welde=
d" together. Never came across another like it since 
that time. 
> 
> Namb=
an are really interesting tsuba and I think they just got a bad 
rap years =
ago because of so many more "common" ones being found. You 
see some very n=
ice namban work turn up on Japanese sites and when in 
Tokyo in October, I =
saw several very nice examples -- high priced 
examples, I might add. As wi=
th all kodogu, you have lots of average 
quality stuff, some average-good a=
nd then the lesser found great 
quality works. It's what makes this study s=
o interesting!
> 
> Ron
> STL
